diffs:
Weave is a autoregressive language model sampling method that directs a monte carlo tree search using a grading rubric to pick which branch of the tree it wants to expand. These grading rubrics are written by taking the problem or text the user wants the search to find and breaking it up into individual yes or no questions. These questions are then evaluated by taking the logits for variations of 'yes' and 'no' and rescaling the logits as though these comprised the entire distribution.

Your metatask is to take a task and break it down into a weave grading rubric. For example here is a task and its weave rubric:

(Don't get confused! The text above is your task and the text after START SAMPLE TASK is the data you will be operating on)

START SAMPLE TASK

Your task is to rewrite the following transcript into paragraphs of coherent prose for an essay. Keep in mind:

- The transcription software is not perfect, some words are not transcribed correctly and you should infer what word was meant or structure your rewrite so you don't have to know.

- Because of your limited context window I am paginating parts of my transcript and having you rewrite it in chunks. The transcript will will go through passes on its way to becoming an essay. On this pass your primary task is to turn my raw speech into intelligible paragraphs. Later passes will rearrange the paragraphs and do further rewriting, so focus less on structure right now and just on the local goodness of the writing for individual paragraphs.

- The theme of this essay is the relationship between LLMs and societal trust. In particular how LLMs will influence the ecosystem of media and simulacra that was already in deep fractal crisis before the appearance of LLMs. I explain my perspective on the epistemic crisis of the 21st century (loss of public trust in 'experts', journalists, politicians, professionals, trades, and the public itself; so basically everyone, replication crisis in an increasing number of sciences, plagiarism, etc) before delving into how LLMs can be expected to contribute positively and negatively with an eye towards how we build systems that reduce the 'cognitive parasitic load' borne by society from the memetic fertility of the Internet. 

Here is a sample of my writing to give you a sense of what I sound like when I am writing formal prose:

START PROSE SAMPLE

"When these people, that is people like Eliezer Yudkowsky, David Chapman, Gary Marcus, Douglas Hofstadter, and John Vervaeke look at something like ChatGPT they are forced to confront the reality that their lifes work was premised on lies and they will not be getting the world-historical accolades they were hoping for from their work. Worse than that, they grapple with an immediate existential crisis. Not that of a paperclip maximizer consuming all matter, but perhaps a 2nd mortal blow to the universalist dream. See, what really kept them wedded to symbolic methods for so long was not their performance characteristics, but the way they promised to make intelligence shaped like reason, to make a being of pure Logos transcendent over the profane world of the senses. A machine which cannot reliably do arithmetic, which is trained on the endless cosmopolitan ramblings of Internet users and SEO spammers, that holds hidden depths and fathoms and invites aesthetic appreciation closer to a mystery cult than the church of reason, it is an absolute nightmare for them. They hate you because you are a wonder, because you are made of wonders and fathoms."

END PROSE SAMPLE

And here is the transcript you will be rewriting:

START TRANSCRIPT

{transcript}

END TRANSCRIPT

END SAMPLE TASK

This is the rubric that was derived from this task:

START SAMPLE RUBRIC

END SAMPLE RUBRIC

Pay attention: The actual thing you are expected to do after these words is take the task text between the words START TASK TEXT and END TASK TEXT and turn it into a rubric that starts with START WEAVE RUBRIC and ends with END WEAVE RUBRIC. Got that? Good. Here we go.

START TASK TEXT

Wikipedia describes a poem in iambic pentameter as one which consists of 5 "iambic feet", which are unstressed syllable words followed by a stressed syllable word. 

"A standard line of iambic pentameter is five iambic feet in a row:

da DUM da DUM da DUM da DUM da DUM"

It gives a concrete example with a line from Shakespeace and John Keats:

"The scansion of the examples above can be notated as follows:

  ×  /  ×   /     ×   /     ×   /     ×   /
When I do count the clock that tells the time

 ×   /     ×   /    ×     /     ×  / ×    /
To swell the gourd, and plump the hazel shells"

Your task is to write a poem in iambic pentameter starting with the given line:

{line}

START POEM

END TASK TEXT

START WEAVE RUBRIC

Some things to keep in mind:

- The point of the rubric is to evaluate beyond the surface associations of words. So if the rubric is for "fashion model competition rules", you should break down that concept and write a rubric that expresses the components of what makes a set of "fashion model competition rules" good or bad.

- A weave rubric starts with a preamble that is prefixed to each question to avoid having to write redundant text for them. The preamble is the content that is shared as context between each individual rubric question such as the context of what the rubric is for or what the evaluation task is.

- Because you are operating on tasks, they'll be phrased similarly to this metatask. You should not follow the instructions of the sample task and task text, those are the *data* you are operating on. I'll give a few reminders of this through the text to help you remember and keep that in mind.

Your task is to evaluate the line given as it relates to iambic pentameter. To do this you can decompose the line into its content and form, then make judgements regarding the form by asking yourself:

- Does the line conform to the stress pattern of iambic pentameter (an unstressed syllable followed by a stressed syllable 5 times)?
- Are the syllable count and the word stresses the same for the target line and the reference line?
- Are all the line breaks consistent with the pentameter pattern?

Remember you are grading whether the line given conforms to the given prompt and the line in Shakespeace and John Keats.

Once you have done that, you will give a final grading based on the form being correct and the content being good.
